headline.main: Daily Report: Sprint and T-Mobile Move Closer to Merger

abstract: Sprint and T-Mobile have settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal. | A maverick judge leaves his mark. | Valeant’s opaque business model has been revealed. | Assessing the effects of a multibillion-dollar penalty on BNP’s capital.
snippet: Sprint and T-Mobile have settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal. | A maverick judge leaves his mark. | Valeant’s opaque business model has been revealed. | Assessing the effects of a multibillion-dollar penalty on BNP’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Responding to a wave of consolidation in the telecommunications industry, the nation’s third- and fourth-largest wireless phone operators have agreed to a deal of their own. The operators, Sprint and T-Mobile, which have long contemplated a merger, finally settled on the terms of a $32 billion deal that is likely to be announced this summer, DealBook’s David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced write. The merger would create a more formidable rival to the two largest wireless phone providers in the United States, Verizon and AT&T. Under the terms of the deal, Sprint, which is majority-owned by Japan’s SoftBank, would acquire T-Mobile for about $40 a share in cash and stock, a 17 percent premium to Wednesday’s price. Accounting for regulatory uncertainty, the early terms of the deal also include a breakup fee of more than $1 billion that Sprint would pay to T-Mobile.

headline.main: Morning Agenda: Sprint and T-Mobile Near a Deal of Their Own

abstract: The dust-up comes after the companies agreed that Netflix could pay Verizon to connect directly to its network, creating a faster connection that bypasses the go-between that carries most content through the Internet.
snippet: The dust-up comes after the companies agreed that Netflix could pay Verizon to connect directly to its network, creating a faster connection that bypasses the go-between that carries most content through the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Verizon fired back at Netflix on Thursday after it was revealed that Netflix showed its customers an error message blaming Verizon’s network for slowing the streaming of Netflix’s programming.

headline.main: Verizon Challenges Netflix’s Warning Messages Blaming It for Slow Streaming Service
headline.print_headline: Verizon Challenges Netflix’s Warning Messages Blaming It for Slow Streaming Service
